title: The Vee Walk Route

nearby.description: Lough Mohra and Rath Beag Loop

images.title: Monument by kevin higgins, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Grubb's Grave. The Vee is also famous as the resting place of Samuel Grubb, whose grave, known as Grubb’s Grave or Grubb’s Monument, stands looking across the Vee Valley, since his death in 1921. It stands on Sugerloaf hill affording some truly glorious views.

images.title: John M / The V of 'The Vee'
images.caption: The V of 'The Vee'. The sharp hairpin bend is known as 'The Vee' giving its name to the road. The road was constructed as a famine relief project in 1846-7 crossing the Knockmealdown Mountains

images.title: Rhododendrons take over the valley by Hywel Williams, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Rhododendrons take over the valley

images.title: Summit of The Vee, Knockmealdown Mtns by Colin Park, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Summit of The Vee, Knockmealdown Mtns

images.title: Bay Lough by Hywel Williams, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Bay Lough

description: Located near the boundary between County Waterford and County Tipperary you'll find the beautiful Vee Gap. Positioned in the dramatic surroundings of the Knockmealdown Mountains it provides a vantage point looking over onto the Galty Mountains further north. You can start the walk from The Vee car park at the southern end of the pretty Bay Lough . The walk then follows a section of the Tipperary Heritage Way , a waymarked long distance trail running through the area. Follow it north and it will take you past Bay Lough before turning east through Bohernagore Wood where you can see some beautiful Rhododendrons. You continue east along pleasant woodland trails before reaching the V-shaped turn on the road after which The Vee Gap is named. You'll reach a height of around 2,000 feet (610m) with wonderful panoramic views over the surrounding mountains and countryside. On a clear day the Vee affords views along and across the valley to Clonmel , Cahir, Ardfinnan, Clogheen, Ballyporeen and even Cashel. The route then heads north to Goaterbridge and finishing in Ardfinnan where there's a fine old bridge over the River Suir.
